div.p: JST Mark title: The Gospel according to St Testimony of St. Mark
Mal. 3:1; Matt. 11:10; Luke 7:27 … Behold, I will send my messenger before thy face, and he which shall prepare thy way before me thee. …
Isa. 40:3 The voice of him one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make straight in the desert a highway for our God his paths straight.
John 1:23 … I am the voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight make straight the way of the Lord …

In. 1 Ne. 10:8; Lehi quotes Isa. 40:3 but his words match the Septuagint and New Testament versions. He then echoes John 1:26–27 (see Matt. 3:11; Mark 1:7; Luke 3:16), perhaps quoting an earlier prophecy, or perhaps as part of a direct revelation.
“Prepare ye the way of the Lord”
make straight (or level, or direct) paths for him
“girdle of a skin about his loins”
leather belt (or band) around his waist
“the latchet of whose shoes I am not worthy to … unloose”
whose sandal strap I am not worthy to … untie
JST Mark 1:6 I indeed have baptized you with water: but he shall not only baptize you with water, but with fire, and the Holy Ghost.
John; see JST Matt. 3:45 (Matt. 3:16 note); John 1:32
“my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased”

(in whom I am well pleased) Matt. 3:17; 17:5; Luke 3:22; 2 Pet. 1:17; 3 Ne. 11:17; (hear ye him) Matt. 17:5; Mark 9:7; Luke 9:35; 3 Ne. 11:7; JS—H 1:17; (in whom I have glorified my name) John 12:28; 3 Ne. 11:7; see 3 Ne. 9:15; (other) D&C 93:15
JST Mark 1:10 And immediately the Spirit driveth took him into the wilderness.
JST Mark 1:11 And he was there in the wilderness forty days, tempted of Satan Satan seeking to tempt him; and was with the wild beasts; and the angels ministered unto him.
city on the north end of the sea of Galilee; Jesus’s home was here in the beginning of his ministry (Mark 2:1)
as soon as it was the Sabbath

synagogue, “assembly,” a house of worship and learning; the Greek ecclesia, “church,” means much the same thing. The Hebrew forms are bet kenesset, “house of assembly,” and bet tefila, “house of prayer”

grammateus: scholars and teachers of the law of Moses and the scriptures. They could also serve as lawyers. They produced scriptures by copying them out, following strict rules to preserve their integrity. They also produced commentaries.
“what have we to do with thee”
what business do you have with us

figure of speech meaning “What business do you have with us,” often with the implication that the situation is unfair. The expression is perhaps similar to the modern “What do you want from me?” or “What have I done to deserve this?”
shaken him; thrown him into convulsions
that is why I have come

The word leprosy was used for a variety of skin diseases. Under the law of Moses, individuals with these diseases were ritually unclean and could not have physical contact with others. Asking to be made pure was the same as asking to be healed.
“publish it much, and to blaze abroad the matter”
speak freely and spread the news
city on the north end of the sea of Galilee; Jesus’s home was here in the beginning of his ministry
being carried by four of them
“uncovered the roof … when they had broken it up”
stripped the roof … made an opening
“Why reason ye these things in your heart”
Why are you thinking these things
JST Matt. 9:5 (Matt. 9:5 note); JST Luke 5:23 (Luke 5:23 note)
“We never saw it on this fashion”
We have never seen anything like this
publicans were public contractors in service to the Roman empire. They commonly served as tax collectors. The Jews commonly saw them as corrupt and as collaborators.
“there were many, and they followed him”
Many people like this followed him
“They that be whole have no need of a physician, but they that are sick”
do not fast; or, are not fasting
fasting is out of the question
“the new piece that filled it up taketh away”
the Pharisees interpreted picking the grain as harvesting
“was an hungred, he, and they that were with him”
when he and his companions were hungry
This should perhaps read “Ahimelech” (Abiathar’s father); see 1 Sam. 21:2

pronounced showbread, also called bread of the presence; i.e., bread kept in the presence of the Lord. This bread was an offering kept perpetually on a table in the holy place before the veil of the temple. When new bread was brought in each sabbath, priests ate the old bread; see Ex. 25:30; Lev. 24:5–9
“which is not lawful to eat but for the priests”
which only the priests are allowed to eat
(26) Wherefore the Sabbath was given unto man for a day of rest; and also that man should glorify God, and not that man should not eat;
(27) For the Son of man made the Sabbath day, therefore the Son of man is Lord also of the Sabbath
so that they could accuse him of something
“grieved for the hardness of their hearts”
supporters of Herod Antipas, Roman governor of Galilee. They often opposed the Pharisees.

Region in the south of Judea, west of the Red Sea. The Idumeans were remnants of Edom, the country of Esau’s descendants. They were conquered in 125 BC by the Jewish Hasmonian king and forced to convert to Judism.
Region east of the Jordan River, to the east of Judea and Galilee, including the Decapolis
Phoenician cities on the Mediterranean coast north of Judea and northwest of Galilee
“he spake to his disciples that a small ship should wait on him”
he told his disciples to have a small boat ready for him
so they would not crowd (or crush) him
And these are the Twelve: Simon …
apparently also known as Judas, brother or son of James; see Matt. 10:3; Luke 6:16
Cananean, Aramean for Zealot; see Luke 6:15. The Zealots were members of a political movement that opposed Roman rule.
He is out of his mind
Lord of the Flies, originally a name for a Philistine god (probably derogatory), later applied to Satan
analogies, brief stories that illustrate a principle
“rise up against himself, and be divided”
rebells against himself, and is divided
that is the end of him
(21) And then came certain men unto him, accusing him, saying, Why do ye receive sinners, seeing thou makest thyself the Son of God.
(22) But he answered them and said, Verily I say unto you, All sins which men have committed, when they repent, shall be forgiven them; for I came to preach repentance unto the sons of men.
(23) And blasphemies, wherewith soever they shall blaspheme, shall be forgiven them that come unto me, and do the works which they see me do.
“and blasphemies wherewith soever they shall blaspheme”

JST Mark 3:24 But there is a sin which shall not be forgiven. He that shall blaspheme against the Holy Ghost, hath never forgiveness; but is in danger of being cut down out of the world. And they shall inherit eternal damnation.
JST Mark 3:25 And this he said unto them because they said, He hath an unclean spirit.
he said this because they said
“and, standing without, sent unto him, calling him
and, standing outside, they sent someone in to call him
“entered into a ship, and sat in the sea”
got in a boat and sat in it out on the water
analogies, brief stories that illustrate a principle
farmers traditionally planted grain by taking handfuls and scattering it evenly on the ground
“immediately it sprang up, because it had no depth of earth”
it sprang up quickly because the soil was shallow
it sprang up quickly, but the soil was shallow
“some thirty, and some sixty, and some an hundred”
some a thirty times more than was planted, some sixty, and some a hundred
“He that hath ears, let him hear”
JST Mark 4:9 And when he was alone with the twelve, and they that believed in him, they that were about him with the twelve asked of him the parable.
asked him to explain the parable
“these are they by the wayside, where the word is sown”
some people are like the seed that fell by the side of the path
in the same way, some people are like the seed that fell stony ground
they stumble; or, they fall away
“these are they which are sown among thorns”
some are like the seed that fell among thorns
some are like the seed that fell
except so that it can be manifested
“If any man have ears to hear, let him hear”
JST Mark 4:20 And he said unto them, Take heed what ye hear: with what measure ye mete, it shall be measured to you: and unto you that hear continue to receive, shall more be given.
vessel for measuring (for example, a teaspoon, a measuring cup, a bushel)
“shall be measured to you: and unto you that hear shall more be given”
will be measured to you, and even more
JST Mark 4:20; For he that hath receiveth, to him shall be given: and but he that hath not continueth not to receive, from him shall be taken even that which he hath.
So is the kingdom of God
This is what the kingdom of God is like
“And should sleep, and rise night and day”
He sleeps at night and is awake during the day
“putteth in the sickle, because the harvest is come”
Joel 3:13 (see Joel 3:9–16); Mark 4:29 (see verses 26–29); John 4:35–36; Rev. 14:14–20; Alma 26:5; D&C 4:4; 6:3–4; etc.
a small, curved hand-tool used for harvesting grain
is the smallest of the seeds
JST Mark 4:33 And with many such parables spake he the word unto them, as they were able to hear it bear;
“without a parable spake he not unto them”
he didn’t speak to them without using a parable
go over to the other side of the lake
“just as he was in the ship”
in the same boat from which he had taught

Inhabitants of Gadara, southeast of the sea of Galilee. Gadara was part of the Decapolis, a group of ten cities, independent under Rome, that were centers of Greek and Roman culture (Jews were a minority).
leg irons; bands or chains placed around the ankles
“what have I to do with thee”

figure of speech meaning “What business do you have with me,” often with the implication that the situation is unfair. The expression is perhaps similar to the modern “What do you want from me?” or “What have I done to deserve this?”
a large military force (a Roman legion consisted of about 5,000 soldiers)
“prayed him that he might be with him”
asked if he could go with him
But Jesus did not let him
“how great things the Lord hath done for thee”
“how great things Jesus had done for them”
“unto him: and he was nigh unto the sea”
around him while he was by the laske
who had suffered from chronic bleeding
“the fountain of her blood was dried up”
“As soon as Jesus heard the word that was spoken”
traveling bag (for food and other necessities)
and do not take an extra shirt (or tunic)
“shake the dust off thy feet … as a testimony against them”
Herod the tetrarch, ruler of Galilee
“therefore mighty works do show themselves in him”
that’s why these miracles are at work in him
like one of the prophets (of old)
had him chained and put in prison
“for Herodias’s sake, his brother Philip’s wife”
because of Herodias, his brother Philip’s former wife

Herodias was granddaughter of Herod the Great, married to her uncle, Philip (probably Herod II, not the same as Philip tetrarch of Iturea—this Philip was as a private citizen in Rome). Herodias divorced Philip so she could marry Herod Antipas, tetrarch of Galilee, also her uncle, and Herod Antipas divorced his wife Phasaelis to marry her.
The law of Moses forbade a man from marrying his brother’s divorced wife (Lev. 20:21). (In some circumstances a man was obligated to marry his brother’s widow; see Deut. 25:5–10.)
to be married to your brother’s former wife

JST Mark 6:20 For Herod feared John, knowing that he was a just man, and a holy man, and one who feared God and observed to worship him, and when he heard him, he did many things for him, and heard him gladly.
“he did many things, and heard him gladly”
he was troubled, but he liked to listen to him (but see JST)

JST Mark 6:21 (not in LDS edition) But when a convenient day Herod’s birthday was come, that Herod on his birthday he made a supper for to his lords, high captains, and chief estates the chief priests of Galilee.
“And when a convenient day was come, that”
But then an opportune time arrived.
“for the oath’s sake, and for their sakes which sat with him”
because the oath and his dinner guests
he did not want to turn her down
JST Mark 6:32 And he said unto them, Come ye yourselves apart into a desert solitary place, and rest a while: for there were many coming and going, and they had no leisure so much as to eat.
“Come ye yourselves into a desert place”
Come with me by yourselves to a solitary place
“many coming and going, and they had
so many people coming and going that they had
JST Mark 6:33 And they departed into a desert solitary place by ship privately.
JST Mark 6:36 And when the day was now far spent, his disciples came unto him, and said, This is a desert solitary place, and now the time is far passed for departure is come; …
denarii; one denarius was a day’s wage
instructed them to have the people
town on the north shore of the sea of Galilee east of the Jordan River
shortly before dawn (the fourth watch was about 3:00–6:00 a.m.)
“went up unto them in the ship”
climbed up into the boat with them
city on the northwest shore of the sea of Galilee, prominent enough that the lake was often called by its name; also the plain stretching south of the city
pleaded with him that the sick
“things there be they have received to hold”
“Why walk not thy disciples according to”

Isa. 29:13 (see also 2 Ne. 27:25) Forasmuch as this … This people draw near me with their mouth, and with their lips do honour me honoureth me with their lips; but have removed their heart is far from me. …
Matt. 15:8 … This people draweth nigh unto me with their mouth, and honoureth me with their lips, but their heart is far from me. …
JS—H 1:19 This people honoureth … they draw near to me with their mouth, and honoureth me with their lips, but their heart is hearts are far from me, …

In Isa. 29:13 the Lord applies this to Jerusalem at the time of the Assyrian siege: they have rejected the book containing “the vision of all,” and because of their apostasy the wisdom of their wise will perish. In 2 Ne. 27:25 Nephi interprets Isaiah 29 in terms of the coming forth of the Book of Mormon. During the First Vision, the Lord used similar phrasing when he tells Joseph Smith not to join any of the churches of the day (JS—H 1:19).
Isa. 29:13 (see also 2 Ne. 27:25) … and their fear toward me is taught by Howbeit in vain do they worship me, teaching for doctrines the precept commandments of men.
Matt. 15:9 But Howbeit in vain do they worship me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men.
JS—H 1:19 … Howbeit in vain they do worship me, teaching they teach for doctrines the commandments of men …
Isa. 29:13; 2 Ne. 27:25; Matt. 15:8–9; JS—H 1:19; see verse 8 notes
“For laying aside the commandment of God, ye hold”
You set aside the commandment of God, and keep
(9) And he said unto them, Full well Yea, altogether ye reject the commandment of God, that ye may keep your own tradition.
(10) Full well is it written of you, by the prophets whom ye have rejected.
(11) They testified these things of a truth, and their blood shall be upon you.
You make an art of rejecting

JST Mark 7:12 Ye have kept not the ordinances of God; for Moses said, Honor thy father and thy mother; and whoso curseth father or mother, let him die the death of the transgressor, as it is written in your law; but ye keep not the law.
“Whoso curseth father or mother, let him die the death”
regarding whatever support you might have gotten
he will be free of his obligation
A person could donate one’s property to God but continue to use it during life. The scribes and pharisees maintained that this gift took precedence over the duty to support one’s parents.
“ye suffer him no more to do ought”
you don’t allow him to do anything more

JST Mark 7:15 There is nothing from without a man, that entering into him can defile him, which is food; but the things which come out of him, those are they that defile the man, that proceedeth forth out of the heart.
“If any man hath ears to hear, let him hear”
Thus Jesus declared all foods clean (but see Matt. 5:18)
(22) And from thence he arose, and went into the borders of Tyre and Sidon, and entered into an house, and would have no man know it that no man should come unto him.
(23) But he could not be hid deny them; for he had compassion upon all men.
Phoenician cities on the Mediterranean coast northwest of Galilee
did not want anyone to know it
a person of Greek language and culture
Syrophenicia; the part of ancient Phoenicia located in the Roman province of Syria, which included Tyre and Sidon. (Another portion of Phoenicia was in Lybia.)
JST Mark 7:26 But Jesus said unto her, Let the children of the kingdom first be filled: for it is not meet to take the children’s bread, and to cast it unto the dogs.
kunarion (household dogs), not the derogatory kuon (street dogs)
Because of your answer, you may go
A group of ten cities, independent under Rome, that were centers of Greek and Roman culture (Jews were a minority). They stretched from Damascus in Syria to east and southeast of the Sea of Galilee
“From whence can a man satisfy these men with bread”
Where could anyone get enough bread to satisfy these people
right after, he got into a boat
unknown location on the shore of the Sea of Galilee; possibly another name for Magdala
“How is it that ye do not understand?”
town on the north shore of the sea of Galilee east of the Jordan River

City built by Philip tetrarch of Iturea in honor of Caesar Augustus. It was located about 25 miles (40 kilometers) north of the Sea of Galilee in a Gentile region at the foot of Mt. Hermon, the source of the Jordan River (in the modern-day Golon Heights).
idiom meaning “leave” (see Matt. 4:10) or perhaps “get back in line” (see 2 Kgs. 9:18–19)

perhaps Jesus is addressing Satan with this phrase, or alluding to Luke 4:8. Or perhaps he means Peter but is using satan as a generic noun (the word means “adversary” in Hebrew), not a name. Or he could be calling Peter a devil, perhaps with at least some irony.
Anyone who wants to follow me
“deny himself, and take up his cross”
Matt. 16:24; JST Matt. 16:25–26 (Matt. 16:24 note); Mark Luke 9:23; 3 Ne. 12:30; see Alma 39:9; Moro. 10:32
“take up his cross, and follow me”

(37) For whosoever will save his life, shall lose it; or whosoever will save his life, shall be willing to lay it down for my sake; and if he is not willing to lay it down for my sake, he shall lose it.
(38) But whosoever shall be willing to lose his life for my sake, and the gospel’s, the same shall save it.
what good does it do someone
(39) … Or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?
(40) Therefore, deny yourselves of these, and be not ashamed of me.

(41) Whosoever therefore shall be ashamed of me and of my words, in this adulterous and sinful generation; of him also shall the Son of man be ashamed when he cometh in the glory of his Father with the holy angels.
(42) And they shall not have part in that resurrection when he cometh.

(42) For verily I say unto you, That he shall come; and he that layeth down his life for my sake and the gospel’s, shall come with him, and shall be clothed with his glory in the cloud, on the right hand of the Son of man.

Mark 9:1 And after six days Jesus taketh with him Peter, and James, and John, who asked him many questions concerning his sayings; and Jesus leadeth them up into an high mountain apart by themselves: and he was transfigured before them.
and his appearance was transformed (see Luke 9:29, but see also D&C 63:21; Moses 1:11, 14)
“so as no fuller on earth can white them”
whiter than anyone on earth could bleach them
JST Mark 9:3 And there appeared unto them Elias with Moses, or in other words, John the Baptist and Moses; and they were talking with Jesus.

Joseph Smith taught, “The Savior, Moses, and Elias, gave the keys to Peter, James, and John, on the mount, when they were transfigured before him” (History of the Church, 3:387); see also D&C 63:21; Moses 1:11, 14
“or in other words, John the Baptist and Moses”
apparently both Elijah and John the Baptist were present
skene; tents or booths (such as those used in the Feast of Tabernacles); the term was also used to describe the tabernacle that served as a temple before Solomon’s Temple was built.
he did not know what to say
“This is my beloved Son: hear him”

(hear him) Matt. 17:5; Luke 9:35; 3 Ne. 11:7; JS—H 1:17; (in whom I am well pleased) Matt. 3:17; 17:5; Mark 1:11; Luke 3:22; 2 Pet. 1:17; 3 Ne. 11:17; (in whom I have glorified my name) John 12:28; 3 Ne. 11:7; see 3 Ne. 9:15; (other) D&C 93:15

JST Mark 9:10 And he answered and told them, Elias verily cometh first, and restoreth prepareth all things; and teacheth you of the prophets; how it is written of the Son of man, that he must suffer many things, and be set at naught.
“Elias verily cometh first, and restoreth all things”
“and how is it written … set at nought. But I say unto you
Then how is it written … set at naught? I tell you

Mark 9:13 But I say unto you, That Elias is indeed come, and they have done unto him whatsoever they listed, as it is written of him; and he bore record of me, and they received him not. Verily this was Elias.
a spirit that makes him unable to speak
it throws him into a seizure
immediately the spirit threw him into a convulsion
rolled around foaming at the mouth
has this been happening to him
What do you mean, “If you can”?
city on the north end of the sea of Galilee; Jesus’s home was here in the beginning of his ministry
“the same shall be last of all”
he must make himself last of all
(34) Whosoever shall receive one of such children in my name, receiveth me humble himself like one of these children, and receiveth me, ye shall receive in my name.
(35) And whosoever shall receive me, receiveth not me only, but him that sent me, even the Father.
causes one of these little ones to stumble; or, places an obstacle in the path of one of these little ones

(40) And Therefore, if thy hand offend thee, cut it off; or if thy brother offend thee and confess not and forsake not, he shall be cut off. It is better for thee to enter into life maimed, than having two hands, to go into hell.

(41) For it is better for thee to enter into life without thy brother, than for thee and thy brother to be cast into hell; into the fire that never shall be quenched, where their worm dieth not, and the fire is not quenched.
if your hand causes you to sin; or, to stumble
be maimed but gain (go into) eternal life
(42) And again, if thy foot offend thee, cut it off; for he that is thy standard, by whom thou walkest, if he become a transgressor, he shall be cut off.
(43) It is better for thee, to enter halt into life, than having two feet to be cast into hell; into the fire that never shall be quenched.
(44) Therefore, let every man stand or fall, by himself, and not for another; or not trusting another.
(45) Seek unto my Father, and it shall be done in that very moment what ye shall ask, if ye ask in faith, believing that ye shall receive.
if your hand causes you to sin; or, to stumble
be lame but gain (go into) eternal life
(46) And if thine eye which seeth for thee, him that is appointed to watch over thee to show thee light, become a transgressor and offend thee, pluck it him out.
(47) It is better for thee to enter into the kingdom of God, with one eye, than having two eyes to be cast into hell fire.
if your eye causes you to sin; or, to stumble
JST Mark 9:48 For it is better that thyself should be saved, than to be cast into hell with thy brother, where their worm dieth not, and where the fire is not quenched.
JST Mark 9:49 (not in KJV) For everyone shall be salted with fire; and every sacrifice shall be salted with salt; but the salt must be good.
Fire may refer to punishment (as in the preceding verses), or the trials that refine us, or to the baptism of fire
“and every sacrifice shall be salted with salt”
Some Greek manuscripts lack this phrase; but see JST

JST Mark 9:50 (not in KJV) Salt is good, but For if the salt have lost his saltness, wherewith will ye season it (the sacrifice)? Therefore, it must needs be that ye have salt in yourselves and have peace one with another.
how will you make it salty again (but see JST)
“of such is the kingdom of heaven”
the kingdom of heaven belongs to such as these
“Why callest thou me good? there is none good but one, that is, God”
“take up his cross, and follow me”
“How hardly shall they that have riches enter”
How hard it is for those with riches to enter

JST Mark 10:26 And Jesus looking upon them saith, With men that trust in riches, it is impossible, but not with God: impossible with men who trust in God and leave all for my sake, for with God all such all these things are possible.
and lands (as well as persecutions), and
JST Mark 10:30 But there are many that are who make themselves first, that shall be last; and the last first.
JST Mark 10:31 This he said, rebuking Peter; and they were in the way going up to Jerusalem
those who are regarded as rulers
show their power … act like tyrants
“whosoever will be great among you, shall be your minister”
“not to be ministered unto, but to minister”
not to be served, but to serve
ancient city about 15 miles (25 kilometers) east-northeast of Jerusalem, west of the Jordan River.
village on the Mount of Olives, a little more than a half mile (1 kilometer) from Jerusalem. The name means “house of unripe figs”
town about 1.5 miles, or 2 kilometers, east of Jerusalem, on the southeast slope of the Mount of Olives.
that no one has ever ridden
What are you doing, untying that colt
“brought a colt … and he sat upon him”
on the colt … on the colt
“Hosanna; Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord”
Ps. 118:24–25 Save now (Hosanna), I beseech thee, O Lord: O Lord, I beseech thee, send now prosperity Hosanna: Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord …
Ps. 118:26 refers to King David, probably in the context of the Feast of Tabernacles. David serves as a type of Christ.
Hosanna: “Save us now!” Used at the Feast of Tabernacles. In other contexts it might be translated “Our Savior!”
(11) Blessed be That bringeth the kingdom of our father David;
(12) Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord; Hosanna in the highest.
“the kingdom of our father David, that cometh in hte name of the Lord”
the coming kingdom of our father David
“that any man should carry any vessel through”
that anyone should carry merchandise in; or, that anyone carrying household wares should take a shortcut through the temple
“My house shall be called a house of prayer”
Isa. 56:7 “for mine house shall be called an house of prayer for all people”
“ye have made it a den of thieves”
Jer. 7:11 “Is this house, which is called by my name, become a den of robbers in your eyes?”
“all men counted John, that he was a prophet”
Ps. 118:22–23 … which the builders refused rejected …
In Ps. 118 the psalmist glorifies the Lord and thanks Him for saving him from his enemies. (The stone that was “refused” may refer to David.)
“neither marry, nor are given in marriage”
“I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob”
“thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thine heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind, and with all thy strength”
“with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind, and with all thy strength”
“Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself”

In Acts 2:34–35, Peter says that David is testifying in this verse that Christ would be resurrected and brought into the Father’s presence. Heb. 1:13 quotes the verse to show that Christ would be greater than the angels. (See additional quotation note below.)
In Ps. 110:1, “my Lord” (my ruler) can refer to David or to Christ. If the verse refers to Christ, then “The Lord” (Jehovah) in this case refers to God the Father.
“until I make thine enemies thy footstool”
until I bring your enemies under your control; see 1 Kgs. 5:3
JST Mark 13 follows JST Matt. 24 fairly closely. JST Matt. 24 is found also in JS—M 1. (See also Matt. 24 and JS—M 1 notes.)
what massive stones; or what wonderful stones
“one stone upon another, that shall not be thrown down”
Matt. 24:6; Luke 21:9; JST Luke 21:9 (Luke 21:9 note); JS—M 1:23, 28
arrest you, and bring you to trial
“take no thought beforehand what ye shall speak … given you in that hour”
“he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved”
“he that shall endure unto the end”

In 168 BC Antiochus IV Epiphanes erected a statue of Jupiter, helping spark the Maccabean revolt (1 Maccabees 1:54 refers to the “abomination of desolation upon the altar”). Christ prophesied that the “abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, concerning the destruction of Jerusalem,” was forthcoming and that not one temple stone would be left upon another (see Matt. 24:2, 15; JS—M 1:3, 12). The temple was destroyed in the Jewish revolt of AD 70, and pagan sacrifices took place on the site Christ said Daniel’s prophecy would be fulfilled again leading up to His Second Coming (see JS—M 1:32; D&C 84:114; 88:85).
that makes desolate, that brings destruction
